scenario:
Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) are expected to become the first $4 trillion companies, according to equity analyst Dan Ives. Ives has raised his 12-month target on Apple to $325 per share, implying a 34% upside from its current share price of $242, and a market value of $4.9 trillion by year-end in 2025. For Microsoft, Ives has set a 12-month target of $550 per share, implying a 31% upside from its current share price of $419, and a market value just above $4 trillion by year-end in 2025.

Apple's premium electronics devices and services business, including iCloud storage, Apple Pay, and Apple TV+, have built loyalty for the company. Apple Intelligence, a suite of AI features, is expected to drive a massive upgrade cycle, with Ives predicting Apple will record its strongest iPhone unit sales in history in the next year. However, Apple's current valuation of 40 times earnings is above the three-year average, and the multiple is hard to justify when Wall Street expects earnings to increase at 10% annually in the next three years.

Microsoft is the largest software company in the world, with a strong presence in other verticals, including business intelligence, enterprise resource planning, and cybersecurity. The company has introduced generative AI copilots and has a strong presence in cloud computing, with its Azure unit being the second-largest cloud infrastructure and platform services provider. Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI creates an onramp to Azure, with usage of Azure OpenAI more than doubling in the past six months. The company is on pace to earn $10 billion in AI revenue in the next quarter, a milestone reached faster than any product in company history. However, Microsoft's valuation of 35 times earnings is also expensive, and the multiple is hard to justify when Wall Street expects earnings to grow at 13% annually in the next three years.
